comments.body: Please add a comment describing the situations `sources == null` and `sources !=null`
Done.

Can a dependency files have comments? Like lines of the form
```# TODO(mravn): remove dependencies on bigwig```
It's technically in 'Makefile' format, which does allow comments. However, gen_snapshot only emits one line containing 'target: sources'.
Does `localEngineOut` refer to the `--local-engine` argument? Then perhaps rename it in the error message.

Not directly. `-PlocalEngineOut` (passed to the Gradle build by Flutter Tools) is the full path to the chosen local engine directory, which is a combination of `--local-engine-src-path` and `--local-engine`. If you don't specify `--local-engine-src-path`, it defaults to `$FLUTTER_ROOT/../engine/src`, but the Gradle build script has no idea about that. It just gets the resolved path.

Flutter Tools will have verified the `--local-engine` argument before passing it to Gradle, so you *should* only see this if you manually specify `-PlocalEngineOut` to gradle. Or, you know, Gremlins.
Do we want to guard this with an `if (project.android.hasProperty("libraryVariants"))` as well, or do we know that Android projects without applicationVariants always have libraryVariants?
We want to fail fast, if we cannot add flutter dependencies. We do that now. Leaving it, as discussed off-line.
comment above at line 75 seems to need to be updated
Done.
Is setting `matchingFallbacks` like this for these dynamic configurations as intended?
I suspect this setting is inconsequential. It only matters if one of flutter's dependency modules doesn't define given build configuration, and I don't see any sub-modules.
cc @mravn-google in case he knows
RSLGTM on the Gradle changes. You may wish to ask @jason-simmons or @matthew-carroll or someone more familiar with Gradle to review these.
Does `"\\\\"` seriously only remove one backslash?  That's a LOT of escaping!
Yeah, what can you do. It feels like regex-syntax should work: `replaceAll(/\\/, "")` but somehow it doesn't.

I'm not sure if it's better to save all these variables to the same kind of flutter jar in this case or leave the ones that don't fit the engine build type null. Either way I think a comment here explaining why these are getting their types clobbered would be good. (/cc @dnfield in case he knows)

My understanding is that this shouldn't change the current behavior - I added a comment to clarify. It may be worth failing the build if the engine isn't built for a particular build type. Anyways, it's clear there's still some work to do here.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +181,185 @@            // The local engine is built for one of the build type.
            // However, we use the same engine for each of the build types.
            debugFlutterJar = flutterJar
            profileFlutterJar = flutterJar
            releaseFlutterJar = flutterJar

comments.body: nit: I think this and the nested lambdas in it would all be easier to follow if they were split out into named functions.

`addFlutterJarApiDependency` needs some work. The closure created by `addFlutterDeps` makes the code a little more difficult to follow. In the meanwhile, I created https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/33064

            targetPlatforms.each { currentTargetPlatformValue ->
                String abiValue = allTargetPlatforms[currentTargetPlatformValue]
                FlutterTask compileTask = project.tasks.create(name: "${flutterBuildPrefix}${variant.name.capitalize()}${currentTargetPlatformValue}:compile",
